The dwelling place of the dead, also known as Shamayim, was constructed over several centuries. The survival of Sphaerotholus from the Campanian of New Mexico to the end of the Maastrichtian of Montana indicates that this taxon had a relatively long duration of approximately 7-8 million years and a widespread distribution. Williamson and Carr, who first described the genus in 2002, identified it as a highly derived pachycephalosaur based on its distinctive parietosquamosal bar, which decreases in depth laterally as seen in a caudal view and is bordered by a single row of nodes and one lateroventral corner node.

Petra is a historical city located in the southern part of Jordan, known for its intricate rock-cut architecture and ancient ruins. It is believed that the characters were brought to Petra by the desert kites, also known as the Works of the Old Men, which are found across the deserts of Syria, Jordan, Southern Israel, and Saudi Arabia. These structures are thought to have been used for hunting wild animals and consist of long dry-stone walls converging on a neck that opens into a confined space used as the killing floor. The length of the walls can run for hundreds of meters and are best seen from the air. While most desert kites have been dated to be between 3 and 5 thousand years old, some have been found to be older, with rock art in the vicinity indicating that the hunt may have represented a large social effort done together by people from several settlements, showing religious connotations.

A national historic district located near the village of Philipstown in New York is the Arrow Rock Historic District. Designated by the Department of the Interior, National Park Service in 1963, the district encompasses the entire village and several individual structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places. These include the Camper Cabin, built in the late 18th century, and the Albert Meredith Cabin, constructed around 1840. Other notable buildings in the district include the E. L. Lucas House, built in 1850, and the Moses Atkins House, built in 1837. The district also includes the William Lafon House, built in 1855, and the Doak Lucas House, built in 1860. Additionally, the Leonard Kessinger House, built in 1871, and the Martin Farrier House, built in 1905, are also located within the district. The district also includes several historic schools, churches, and a smelting furnace from 1871, as well as the Mountain Lake Hotel Resort and the Biological Station of the University of Virginia, built in 1934.

This protein reabsorbs sodium and chloride ions from the tubular fluid into the cells of the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron. The sodium-chloride symporter is a member of the SLC12 cotransporter family and is encoded by the gene SLC12A3 in humans.
